title: How to Use an Onsen

steps.headline: Remove your shoes or slippers before entering.
steps.description: Before visiting the changing area or the bath itself, look around for signs that tell you to take off your shoes or slippers. If you don’t see any instructions, remove your shoes as a polite precaution. In many onsens, it’s considered pretty disrespectful to wear your shoes into the changing or bathing area. If you aren’t sure what you’re supposed to do, follow the crowd! Locals are sure to know the rules and regulations for the onsen.

steps.headline: Go into the onsen that matches your gender identity.
steps.description: Look for a red or blue drape hanging in front of the onsen entrance. The red curtain has the kanji, or Japanese letter, for “woman” (女), while the blue curtain has the kanji for “man” (男). Since most onsens are separated by gender, enter the bath that best matches your gender or gender identity.While it’s not common, some onsens will have a bathing area for everyone. These entrances will be labeled with a sign or drape with the kanji for “mixed bathing” (混浴).

steps.headline: Take off your clothes before entering the bath area.
steps.description: You have to be completely naked in order to enter the bath. It’s completely understandable if you feel a bit out of your comfort zone for this! If you don’t like the idea of getting changed in front of everyone, drape a small towel in front of your chest or back to give yourself a little privacy.You can bring your own hand towel, or you can borrow or rent 1 from the facility. You’ll be taking the small hand towel with you to the baths, so you can keep yourself covered throughout your visit to the onsen.

steps.headline: Place your belongings in a provided container.
steps.description: Look along the side wall of the changing room for a row of baskets. Keep your clothes, shoes, towels, and any other belongings in this basket, as you’re not allowed to take much with you into the bath.If possible, see if you can store your belongings in a secure locker.

steps.headline: Bring a small towel, hair tie, and bath products when you go to the bath.
steps.description: If you have a specific soap, shampoo, or conditioner that you’d like to shower with, bring those bottles with you. It’s also fine if you don’t have any bath products with you, it. If your hair goes past your chin or shoulders, consider bringing a hairband with you, as well.As a general rule of thumb, you don’t want your hair soaking in the communal bath water. If you brought your own bath products, there should be a basket near the shower where you can keep them.

steps.headline: Sit at a showering station before entering the onsen.
steps.description: As you enter the bathing area, look for a wall with water taps, moveable showerheads, and small stools. Since the showering area is pretty compact, you need to stay seated on the provided stool as you wash yourself off. Don’t stand while you use the shower, as this may be considered rude to other guests. If you see someone else’s bath products near a specific stool or showerhead, assume that the area is being used by another person.

steps.headline: Wash yourself using your soap, shampoo, and a provided bin.
steps.description: The caretakers at the onsen may give you a wooden or plastic bin, which you can fill with soapy or clean water. You can dip your hand towel in or use the bin to rinse yourself off. It all depends on your own personal preference.

steps.headline: Rinse off with the provided showerheads so you aren’t soapy.
steps.description: Move the showerhead slowly and carefully, so you don’t splash anyone by accident. Some onsens will turn off the water supply if a shower isn’t being used, so you may have to pull or push on the tap lever multiple times to get the water going.If you’re worried about splashing someone with the showerhead, consider using the provided bin instead. Make sure that you’ve rinsed off all the soap and shampoo leftover from your shower. You don’t want to track suds into the onsen!

steps.headline: Wring out your hand towel so there’s no soap leftover.
steps.description: Soak your towel in clean water, then wring it out completely. Make sure that there’s no soup or suds stuck in the cloth, since you’ll be reusing this towel again.

steps.headline: Clean up the shower area when you’re done.
steps.description: Use the showerhead to rinse off the outside of the stool. Pick up any of your old bath products so the shower is in tip-top shape for the next guest.Since nobody is wearing clothes in the onsen, it’s nice etiquette to clean off the stool when you’re done using it.

steps.headline: Step slowly and quietly when you enter the onsen.
steps.description: Be courteous of the other guests so you don’t splash them by accident. Find an open area where you can sit and lounge without encroaching on anyone’s personal space. Don’t bring your bath products into the onsen with you. Instead, return them to your bin in the changing room.

steps.headline: Fold and store your hand towel so it’s not in the bath water.
steps.description: Keep your bath towel on the edge of the onsen, or fold it into a small square. For a more sanitary solution, perch the towel on top of your hair.Since the onsen is communal, you don’t want to contaminate your towel with anyone else’s germs.

steps.headline: Avoid getting your face or hair wet with the onsen water.
steps.description: Don’t dunk your head beneath the water or try to splash water on your face. If your hair is especially long, use an elastic band to tie it into a bun or ponytail.Onsen water can be on the acidic side, so you don’t want it touching your face.

steps.headline: Be polite and respectful of the other patrons.
steps.description: Say hello to the other guests as you enter the onsen, and feel free to strike up a conversation. Don’t shout, swim around in the bath, or do anything else that would disrupt another patron’s stay at the onsen. With this in mind, don’t smoke or drink any alcohol while you’re soaking in the bath.Be courteous to everyone visiting the onsen. Avoid staring or otherwise being rude.

steps.headline: Sit on the edge of the bath if you feel overheated.
steps.description: While onsens are relaxing, you may find yourself feeling woozy or overheated if you spend a lot of time soaking. Feel free to scoot onto the side wall or platform of the onsen, using your hand towel to cover up as needed.Some onsens can be as hot as 42 °C (108 °F), so it’s completely normal if you feel overheated after awhile.Did you know? If the onsen water is very hot, you should only stay in the bath for about 10 minutes. If the water is comfortably warm, you can stay for up to 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Visit the showering station after your bath if you’d like to clean off.
steps.description: Depending on your own grooming routine, you may want to shower again before going back to the changing room. You can also take a cool shower if you’re feeling especially overheated. You don’t have to shower after soaking in the onsen, but you’re welcome to if you’d like.

steps.headline: Dry off with your hand towel so you’re not dripping wet.
steps.description: Unfold your hand towel and blot away any leftover water from the onsen. While you don’t have to be completely dry, you don’t want to re-enter the changing room while you’re dripping wet.

steps.headline: Use your large towel to finish drying off in the changing area.
steps.description: Return to the changing room and find the locker or basket where you stored your belongings. Find a bench or other secluded area in the changing room where you can dry yourself off privately.Some onsens have a lot of amenities in their changing rooms, like hair dryers, sinks, and vending machines.

steps.headline: Get changed into dry clothes after your bath.
steps.description: Slip back into the clothes you were wearing before, or a set of clean clothes if you brought them along. If you need to dry your hair or reapply any makeup, feel free to do so in the changing area. To be courteous, don’t put on your shoes until you’ve completely exited the onsen.
